awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: MODULUS: A Novel Spatiotemporal Multifractal Analysis to Evaluate Genome Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Currently there remains an incomplete understanding of how genomic information translates into organismal phenotypes, how environmental signals alter the flow of molecular information, and how biology's hierarchical organization of genomic information impacts information processing and genome dynamics over short and long-periods of time. This project integrates biological and mathematical methods to model and investigate mechanisms through which genomic information responds to change across multiple scales. Using statistical-physics and analytical methods typically applied to characterizing fractal-properties of non-biological systems, investigators explore the complex interdependency between chromosome organization, genome activity and genome evolution.  Results of the work will further understanding of the genome-to-phenome relationship and spatiotemporal cross-dependencies governing the fungal genomic architecture.  Through an immersive laboratory exchange program students participating in the project will receive a unique interdisciplinary training experience at the intersection of biology and mathematics.  Investigators will also engage various cohorts of learners through the University of Southern California's Viterbi Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) and Kansas State University's Girls Researching Our World (GROW) programs.  

There is a great need to decode the complex interdependency between chromosome organization, genome activity and genome evolution and understand the genome-to-phenome relationships modulated by biological processes that span multiple spatial and temporal scales. The interdisciplinary team of investigators will use multi-fractal analysis, statistical physics and differential geometry to model and identify causal links in information processing across high-dimensional data describing chromatin dynamics. Key research objectives of the project include: 1) Development of a mathematical framework that integrates multidimensional genomic information in order to quantify the multi-scale nature of genome structure and predict the phenomenological consequences associated with temporally and environmentally driven genomic modulation; 2) Determination of the information processing machinery and multi-scale characterization of the flow of genetic information in concordance to changes in genome organization and environmental stress;  3) Using the mathematical framework developed, investigate whether DNA changes are purely random or if and to what extent physical, chemical and environmental stressors inform the formation of genomic regions of high evolvability.  Outcomes of this project will provide insight into broader organizational principles of fungal and eukaryotic genomes. 

This award was co-funded by Systems and Synthetic Biology in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Mathematical Biology Program of the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The collaborative research project titled ‘A Novel Spatiotemporal Multifractal Analysis to Evaluate Genome Dynamics’ supported research in the labs of Dr. David Cook and Dr. Paul Bogdan at Kansas State University and University of Southern California, respectively. The project was funded through the Models for Uncovering Rules and Unexpected Phenomena in Biological Systems (MODULUS) program at the National Science Foundation. The project helped support research in the Cook lab that resulted in 10 peer-reviewed publications, three manuscripts under peer-review, a completed dissertation and completed thesis, and supported the training of two postdocs, two graduate students, and two undergraduates in the Cook lab. We additionally released code and genomic data resources to publicly available repositories to support open and continued research.

 The research has led to three significant intellectual contributions. Firstly, as a cross-disciplinary research project, we have developed new algorithms and approaches to quantify and analyze biological data. This includes the application of geometric analysis to biological networks to infer functional relationships, the use of multifractal and differential geometry analysis to genomic data for dimensional reduction and feature selection, and the application of machine learning algorithms to detect patterns in biological and genomic data to infer function. Research results from these approaches have been published in peer-review journals, presented at scientific meetings, and the code has been released to allow other researchers to apply the methods to additional datasets. Secondly, the research project has helped identify patterns in genomic data beyond the linear DNA sequence, that are associated with genome evolution. This includes how the epigenome characterized through chemical histone modifications, and DNA organization characterized through physical DNA contacts, contain patterns reflective of genome evolution in populations of fungal plant pathogens. These are novel findings of an unexpected dependence between chemical and physical genomic characteristics and long-term genome trajectory. Lastly, we modeled a general transcriptional response during plant infection that is predictive of plant disease development across a wide range of plant-microbe interactions. This suggests a conserved signaling pattern across the analyzed pathosystems that includes plant infection to fungi and bacteria. The identified genes have largely been unexplored in the context of plant immunity, and may represent unknown components or patterns of the plant immune response. Together, these research outcomes describe new applications of geometric and multifractal analysis to biological data sets to understand gene and genome function.

 The project had broader impacts that strengthen the US workforce, promote diversity in science, and address pressing national and international concerns related to pathogen biology and agricultural production. Trainees in the Cook lab were mentored in molecular biology and bioinformatics related to plant-fungal interactions. These are important high-skill areas needed to support private industry and the (bio)economy. The project supported trainees across the span of career stage, gender, nationality, and socioeconomic background, increasing participation and diversity in STEM careers. This was further supported by professional development and science communication opportunities, such as University open houses and scientific meetings, where lab members engaged with the public to disseminate their findings and develop their communication skills. Another important outcome of the research project was cross-disciplinary team training received by members of the Cook and Bogdan lab. Through regular weekly online meetings, students learned to communicate across scientific disciplines including Biology and Mathematics to define research questions, objectives and results. This is a key objective in the training of scientists able to tackle complex problems requiring multidisciplinary science. Lastly, our results advance our understanding of fungal pathogen evolution and the plant immune system, which benefits society. There is a growing concern over the rise of fungal pathogens threatening agricultural and animal health, and our novel insights inform our understanding of the mechanisms and factors contributing to fungal genome evolution.  Our discovery of novel genes predictive of disease outcome to diverse pathogens provides a new avenue to improve crop protection to pathogens to improve stability and economic output in our agricultural economy.
